title: Referencing
text:
How to reference

if you use a source in a substantive way when writing, include a short and stereotyped mention of that source (aka a reference)

title: Referencing
text:
Why reference?

to show where an idea comes from - the scholarly breadcrumb trail
to fend off controversy when introducing difficult ideas
to save yourself work
to avoid allegations of impropriety

title: Referencing
text:
Referencing styles

there are lots of different styles
no-one agrees which is best/correct/right
pedants delight in the details, and you will often see minor differences in style in different places. See the narcissism of small differences - by and large, the details are irrelevant and pointless
clarity and consistency beats, by a long way, specific scheme trivia
if in doubt, ask two simple questions:

title: Referencing
text:
The key questions

can you find your source from your reference?
are my references consistent across my work

Vancouver (AMA)

each work is numbered by order of appearance
use that number in the text as your citation: (2)

ordered list of end-notes as your bibliography:



O‚ÄôNeil C. Weapons of Math Destruction: How Big Data Increases Inequality and Threatens Democracy. London: Allen Lane; 2016.


Harvard

each work gets a unique author-year identifier
that identifier is used in the text as your citation: (O'Neil, 2016)

bibliography ordered by first-author surname and year:


O‚ÄôNeil, Cathy. 2016. Weapons of Math Destruction: How Big Data Increases Inequality and Threatens Democracy. London: Allen Lane.

Which to use?
Harvard

strengths

Allows pin-point referencing of single pages
Great when readers are likely to be familiar with some sources
Easy to troubleshoot


weaknesses

Verbose and distracting, particularly if you have lots of references in a single sentence - (3-11) rather than (see Smith, 1901; Smith, 1902; Smith, 1903)

Harder to create


Vancouver

strengths

Concise
Great for short papers with comparatively few references


weaknesses

Bad for per-page pinpoint references
Ungainly for longer documents
Edits might necessitate renumbering

the in-text citation
the end-of-document reference

Different types of source need different handling

here‚Äôs a link to a (famous) journal article

please could you repeat your referencing exercise using this different source?

title: Referencing
text:
Referencing tools
Word referencing

many people just typing in references manually at the foot of the document
this is probably the best way of working if you‚Äôre dealing with a very few references (say, less than 10)
but there‚Äôs an inflection point at about 10 references, where the manual approach gets horrid
Word referencing how-to

you‚Äôll need the citation tools menu  

add a reference by Manage Sources 

select a reference style (APA is approximately Harvard)
add in-text citations with Insert Citation

add a bibliography with Bibliography

Pros and cons of Word referencing

‚úîÔ∏è quick and convenient
‚úîÔ∏è uses a familiar tool
‚ùå need to download dubious add-ons to change style
‚ùå bibliographic data needs manually-entering, and is hard to re-use

title: Referencing
text:
Refworks

The Knowledge Network resources on Refworks

Bibtex

FOSS- and code-friendly format for storing bibliographic data
widely-interpretable

@article{oneil2016, 
  author = "Cathy O'Neil", 
  Title = {Weapons of Math Destruction: How Big Data Increases Inequality and Threatens Democracy}, 
  publisher = "Allen Lane",
  city = "London",
  YEAR = 2016, 
} 

e.g.¬†adding [@oneil2016] in Quarto generates a citation: (O‚ÄôNeil 2016)

and we‚Äôll gain a bibliography at the end of the slides
Pros and cons of bibtext

‚úîÔ∏è powerful and flexible
‚úîÔ∏è allows you to manage large bibliographies with big serious tools (like JabRef)
‚ùå finding clean data is a challenge, and manual tidying is tedious
‚ùå for the code-friendly, or code-curious

A user supplies some input. That input is fed into an input node(s), which processes the input, and produces three different outputs that are then fed into a second layer of nodes. Further processing happens in this hidden layer, leading to three outputs that are integrated together in a final output node that processes the outputs of the hidden layer into a single output.

title: Neural nets made ridiculously simple
text:
Several kinds of networks

there are lots of ways that neural networks can be arranged
our example above = feed-forward

all the nodes are connected from left-to-right


but more complex architectures - like recurrent neural networks - might have feedback looks and other biological-ish features
different numbers of layers
lots of different design tendencies since the first intro of neural nets in the 1950s [@rosenblatt1958]

title: Neural nets made ridiculously simple

Why ANNs?

ANNs can can potentially replicate any input-output transformation
we do that by a) increasing complexity and b) allowing them to ‚Äòlearn‚Äô

title: Neural nets made ridiculously simple
text:
How do hidden layers help?

all this complexity allows input to be processed differently
like neurones, downstream nodes either fire (activate) or do not fire depending on their inputs
to understand how that takes place, we need three new ideas:

an activation function which determines how a node fires in response to its input input
a set of input weights which set the strength of each input. Higher weighted inputs are more likely to activate

bias = the strength of a node‚Äôs output. Higher bias = higher chance of our node‚Äôs output firing the downstream node

Training in neural networks

ANNs can be trained

take a dataset
split it into training and test parts

classify (by hand) the training data


then train

feed your ANN the training data and evaluate how well it performs
modify the ANN based on that evaluation
repeat until done/bored/perfect


finally, test your model with your unlabelled test data and evaluate

title: Neural nets made ridiculously simple
section: Training is about weights and biases
text:
Training is about weights and biases

varying weights and biases changes how our network responds to input
you might start with random weights/biases, or with everything set to 1, or something more complicated
training works by varying weights and biases across the network, and evaluating the overall response across the training data. Call that an epoch


LeCun initialization: In this method, you would follow a formula that considers the number of inputs and outputs to create random weights that represent a series of numbers, all with an equal probability of being the starting weight.
Xavier initialization: This method is similar to the LeCun method but is used in Keras and takes a square root of the initialization values you would get from a LeCun method.
He initialization: A method useful for deep learning, He initialization uses an activation function to assign weights.

title: Effective writing tips and tricks
text:
About this session

this session is about writing for analytical purposes
this is an intermediate-level session, so it‚Äôs aimed at people with prior professional experience of analytical writing
it‚Äôs largely hints-and-tips, rather than deeply philosophical
it‚Äôs based on Paul J. Silva‚Äôs excellent 2007 book How To Write A Lot, with appropriate translations to non-academic writing
it‚Äôs also one of the rare training sessions with a single right answer: schedule your writing

title: Effective writing tips and tricks
text:
Writing is hard

writing is hard
but we also make writing much harder than it needs to be
that makes writing unpleasant
which produces poor results
and there‚Äôs a doom-loop: those self-inflicted worries make subsequent writing harder

title: Effective writing tips and tricks
text:
Writing is a teachable skill

understand what writing is
what you need to write
when to write
schedule, plan, and monitor
keep the style simple

title: Effective writing tips and tricks
text:
What writing is

anything that gets the project done counts as writing
anything that doesn‚Äôt, doesn‚Äôt
that includes planning, scheduling, thinking, etc. Anything that ultimately leads to getting words on the page

title: Effective writing tips and tricks
text:
What you need to write

loads of utter bilge written about this, but basically two necessary components only:

time (we‚Äôll discuss below)
space


you probably can‚Äôt fit a writing project into your current schedule without some readjustments

title: Effective writing tips and tricks
text:
I don‚Äôt feel like writing
Silva 2007: 25: you write three times as much if you schedule your writing time, and force yourself to write

title: Effective writing tips and tricks
text:
Schedule, plan, and monitor

massive blocks of time are a trap (binge writing)
what you need is a schedule: ‚Äúthe terrible power of habit‚Äù
add a regular writing slot to your schedule:

do it it Teams
stick to it
don‚Äôt give it up for anything
monitor your compliance

title: Effective writing tips and tricks
section: What to do with your schedule?
text:
What to do with your schedule?

figure out your project aim(s): each a single sentence that describes what the project needs to do
break those aims down into a plan
use the plan to give yourself concrete daily goals
monitor those goals and reward yourself for meeting them
rewards can be anything except days off writing

title: Effective writing tips and tricks
text:
Concrete daily goals

write 50 words in section xxxx
plan section headings for xxxx
review data and plan maps for xxxx
write text around maps for xxxx
proof-read section xxxx

title: Effective writing tips and tricks
text:
More on planning

we can usually find/steal a formula to work from by reading work with similar aims
steal their structure and populate it to suit your project aim
get feedback on your plan

title: Effective writing tips and tricks
text:
Recursive planning

take your project aim
you now need 3-5 points that:

support/explain/make up your main aim
each point should be a simple sentence


then repeat: 3-5 points for each point, and so on

you should almost certainly stop one layer of detail before you think you‚Äôve said enough

title: Effective writing tips and tricks
text:
Write to the plan

write a horrible first draft

fill-in-the-blanks of your plan
don‚Äôt sweat anything other than the main aim: does this work stick to the topic, and cover all the ground you need to


schedule time to re-work this draft into a second-draft

make it simple: prefer cutting rather than adding
put in into English


get feedback on that approximate second draft

title: Effective writing tips and tricks
text:
Push the message

you‚Äôre definitely an expert
but your reader doesn‚Äôt need to be an expert

and

you‚Äôve worked for hours on this
but your reader skimmed

and

you know how each piece of the work will eventually fit into the work as a whole
but your reader doesn‚Äôt

and

you think your graphs and tables speak for themselves
but your reader doesn‚Äôt know the context, and doesn‚Äôt understand what you‚Äôre trying to show them

title: Effective writing tips and tricks
text:
Style tips

mind the technical jargon

minimise, standardise, and define


remove

the non-technical jargon
parasitic intensifiers (quite, totally, very, basically, completely, ‚Ä¶)


parallel sentences are excellent for analytics

‚ÄúIn the first group, something happened. In the second group, nothing happened.‚Äù
‚ÄúWe did a thing. Those with cars responded. Those without cars did not.‚Äù

text:
Packages vs modules
We‚Äôll load the pandas module in Python, and the readr package in R (Wickham, Hester, and Bryan 2024) to compare and contrast loading external functions. We‚Äôll use those to read some sample data (the KIND book of the week dataset).


Python
R




botw_dat = "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/NES-DEW/KIND-community-standards/main/data/KIND_book_of_the_week.csv"

import pandas
botw = pandas.read_csv(botw_dat)

But we also have a lot of options for loading modules. We can alias, most usefully to give us short names for commonly-used functions:

import pandas as pd
botw = pd.read_csv(botw_dat)

We could even load an individual function from a module:

from pandas import read_csv as read_csv
botw = read_csv(botw_dat)

# one minor bit of cheating - we'll coerce the Year column to numeric
botw = botw.replace("1979 (1935)", 1979)
botw = botw.replace("2015 / 2017", 2015)
botw["Year"] = pandas.to_numeric(botw["Year"])



There are comparatively fewer options for package loading in R. You‚Äôd traditionally attach a whole package using library:

library(readr)

botw_dat <- "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/NES-DEW/KIND-community-standards/main/data/KIND_book_of_the_week.csv"

botw <- read_csv(botw_dat)

You can load individual functions by namespacing via :::

botw <- readr::read_csv(botw_dat)

It is also possible, although non-standard, to alias individual functions:

steve <- readr::read_csv
botw <- steve(botw_dat)

text:
Loops, list comprehensions, and vectorization
There are various methods for repeatedly running code. We‚Äôll demonstrate a couple of simple methods here. Note that both Python and R have rich and powerful functional programming tools available (like map), but we‚Äôll park those for now.


Python
R



You‚Äôll need to use loops, or (much nicer) list comprehension in Python. There‚Äôs no exact counterpart of R‚Äôs vectorized functions:

double_numbers_loop = []

for n in numbers_list:
    double_numbers_loop.append(n * 2)

double_numbers_loop

[10, 8, 6, 4, 2]


List comprehension
Like a lovely lightweight loop syntax

double_numbers_list =  [n*2 for n in numbers_list]
double_numbers_list

[10, 8, 6, 4, 2]

# and, more fancy...
double_even_numbers_list =  [n*2 for n in numbers_list if (n%2 == 0) ]
double_even_numbers_list

[8, 4]





By and large, R is at its best with vectorized functions:

double_numbers_vector <- numbers_vector * 2
double_numbers_vector

[1]  2  4  6  8 10


Loops are possible too

double_numbers_loop <- vector("numeric", length = length(numbers_vector))

for (i in numbers_vector) {
  double_numbers_loop[i] <- i * 2
}

R has copy-on-modify semantics, and so care needs to be taken to avoid writing poorly-performing loops. That means that loops are used comparatively rarely in R.

Objective: To determine whether remote, retroactive intercessory prayer, said for a group of patients with a bloodstream infection, has an effect on outcomes.

title: An introduction to EBM (session 3)
text:
Spurious causes

Intervention: In July 2000 patients were randomised to a control group and an intervention group. A remote, retroactive intercessory prayer was said for the well being and full recovery of the intervention group.
Main outcome measures: Mortality in hospital, length of stay in hospital, and duration of fever.
Results: Mortality was 28.1% (475/1691) in the intervention group and 30.2% (514/1702) in the control group (P for difference=0.4). Length of stay in hospital and duration of fever were significantly shorter in the intervention group than in the control group (P=0.01 and P=0.04, respectively).


These results, however, need to be interpreted with caution. There was no significant difference between the two groups with regard to the most clinically important outcome (mortality), and the median values varied little between prayer and non-prayer on both length of stay (seven and eight days) and duration of fever (two days each). The religious affiliation of the person saying the prayer is not given. Many religious groups do not accept the power of prayer given by those with different beliefs. If real, the effect of prayer shown in this study may be unrelated to supernatural power and hence to a particular belief system, or may be specific to beliefs, reflecting the power inherent in a particular religion. Further work is needed in this area before conclusions can be made. (Thornett 2002)

title: Presenting
text:
Be simple

if in doubt, take it out

Why be simple?

the asymmetry of presentation:

you‚Äôll know much more than your audience
so you‚Äôll worry about details, not basics
but your audience will need the basics, not the details


simple = clear
How to be simple?

apply a hierarchy
recursive planning
use your constraints
The hierarchy

you‚Äôll need a single sentence that sums up your presentation

everything else comes from this


ideally you‚Äôll have it in mind before you start

but it often changes


this is non-negotiable, and much harder than it looks
Task: make a sentence

you‚Äôre going to present something you did this week at work
can you sum it up in one sentence?

that‚Äôs your win of the week sentence too


several example prompts

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs most important?‚Äù
‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs most interesting?‚Äù
‚Äúwhat needs fixing?‚Äù
‚Ä¶


Recursive planning

you now need 3-5 points that:

support/explain/make up your main point
each point should be a simple sentence


then repeat: 3-5 points for each point, and so on

you should almost certainly stop one layer of detail before you think you‚Äôve said enough


Task: support your sentence

‚ÄúI managed to fix my booking system‚Äù

‚Äúbooking clinic slots was done manually‚Äù
‚Äúthat was slow and error-prone‚Äù
‚ÄúI used PowerAutomate + very strong language to automate it‚Äù
‚ÄúI had to learn to use Apply to Each to get that to work‚Äù
‚ÄúI am now thinking about automating my other clinic bookings‚Äù


Constraints

take your plan, and chop it down to size by considering:

how long do you have to speak, exactly?

one point every two minutes is pretty good going


how long do you have to prepare?

see below‚Ä¶


who are your audience?

the less closely they‚Äôre related to your work, the less material you‚Äôre going to cover


how big is the audience?

bigger = messier = less detail




Tech

it‚Äôs hard to give general advice, but think carefully about your specific tech
tech often malfunctions during presentations, so you might have a backup (e.g.¬†what to do if you can‚Äôt show your slides?)
you‚Äôll also be more likely to make mistakes with the tech when speaking

title: Presenting
text:
Be keen

enthusiasm for your work, for your audience, and for what you‚Äôre presenting about is the easiest way to come off as knowledgeable and interesting
plenty of preparation helps
but for most of us this is scary
fake it with socially-approved cheating!

excited vs scared
smile, eye contact, and a bit of hand gesturing
build yourself a few lines to say at the start. Introductions work well. Don‚Äôt be afraid of being blunt!
give yourself a sentence in and out of each slide/section
build yourself some go-tos if you get stuck or the tech explodes



Practice time!

we‚Äôll work in pairs
you‚Äôve got a sentence, and 3-5 supporting bits
we‚Äôre going to get you to present for two minutes only, no visual aids - just chat
we‚Äôll pause here to let everyone put their sentences in order
then into pairs:

one minute to find your feet
two minutes presenting
one minute of gentle, constructive, and positive feedback
then swap


Prep time

if you‚Äôre new at this, or it‚Äôs important, I would budget a huge amount of time to prepare

one hour preparation per minute of speaking (seriously)


this time isn‚Äôt for doing the work you‚Äôre presenting

it‚Äôs just for planning the presentation


beware procrastination by optimization (especially making slides before you‚Äôve decided what you‚Äôre going to say)
Slides

recursive plan + pictures = slides
fewer than 20 words per slide
usual advice is 2 minutes per slide
put your details at the start and end

title: Presenting
text:
Be human

don‚Äôt try and cover everything
absolutely leave time for Q+A (and ideally a bit of random chat) at the end
don‚Äôt apologise, but do admit when things go wrong

there‚Äôs asymmetry here too: your clunker will look like a mini-hitch to the audience



Make it easy for yourself

title: Writing effective surveys
text:
Introduction

surveys: groups of questions designed to help you understand something in a population
quick and low-tech way of gathering information about a topic
definitely different from ‚Äòproper‚Äô qualitative research, etc
closed (and usually simple) questions
not tech-specific: paper, in-person, web form‚Ä¶
usually completed by the members of that sample directly (or their advocate) rather than by a professional

title: Writing effective surveys
text:
Of note

local National worries about survey responses
survey-logic informs big, serious, decisions
surveys are often extremely badly put together

title: Writing effective surveys
text:
The population

the key idea to build useful surveys: what‚Äôs the population?
population: some specified group of people - service users, general public, left-handed furriers from Dundee‚Ä¶
surveys will usually be asked of a sample of a population (unlike a census, where everyone replies)

title: Writing effective surveys
text:
Core survey ideas

topic: what‚Äôs the survey about?
coverage: who can fill in the survey?
sample: who actually did fill in the survey?
completion: who completed the survey questions?
discrimination: what did the different answers tell us about our topic?

title: Writing effective surveys
text:
An example: favourite TV show

surveys are often about complicated topics

if it‚Äôs easy, you don‚Äôt need a survey!

we‚Äôre going to start with a simple topic: what TV programmes do people like?

title: Writing effective surveys
text:
Before we start‚Ä¶
Some questions for you:

do we really understand our topic well enough to turn it into questions?
what‚Äôs the population we‚Äôre interested in?
how should we get good coverage (and what does good look like for us?)

title: Writing effective surveys
text:
Quick wins

be specific
identify a specific population, and tailor the survey to them
worry about completion (and include that in your results)
have a plan about how to use the results (and maybe work backwards from that)

title: Writing effective surveys
text:
Questions

what questions do we need to ask people to find out about our topic?
how do they need to be adapted to work for our population?
what does it tell us about our topic?
what are we trying to discriminate?

title: Writing effective surveys
text:
Contradictory suggestions about questions
A personal rationale for these contradictory bits of advice: keeping users happy and engaged is key to writing good survey questions. It should be obvious what a question is getting at, why it‚Äôs being asked.

suggestion: align your questions with your topic, and make it obvious. Don‚Äôt leave users pondering questions like ‚ÄúI wonder why they‚Äôre interested in that??‚Äù
suggestion: make your questions discriminate between different options, and make each of your questions obviously different. Avoid 29 fractionally-different questions about basically the same thing
suggestion: include absolutely as few questions as possible

title: Writing effective surveys
text:
Why so short?
Most people have some degree of survey fatigue. Don‚Äôt make that worse by writing a three-volume epic. Tread lightly on your respondent‚Äôs time, and make it clear what the benefit of answering is.

long surveys have poor discrimination (because people get bored)
long surveys have poor response rates
let users pick options rather than generate text themselves wherever possible
long surveys produce sampling problems, where only the most motivated will complete. And the views of the most motivated don‚Äôt reflect the views of most people.







Reminder



sample: who actually did fill in the survey?
completion: who completed the survey questions?
discrimination: what did the different answers tell us about our topic?

title: Writing effective surveys
text:
Then, after the data collection‚Ä¶

what sort of sample did we get?

how does that compare with our planned coverage?
what did our completion look like?

analysis (non-technical!)
what do we do with the results?

title: Writing effective surveys

That‚Äôs a lot to think about!

so let‚Äôs try to look at the core analytical decisions by looking at a terrible survey
